FILE OES1=APPEND $ OFPINDX /OES1 $OFPINDX Creates an index into an OFP table OFPINDX /OFPDB $ OFPDB Table suitable for input to the OFP module

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Retrieves, prints and stores information concerning an op2 file.2338 Main Index Provides information on the topology and content of the output2 file associated with the unit number at parameter location 1. Format: Input Data Blocks: None. Output Data Blocks: Parameters:OP2INFO Retrieves, prints and stores information concerning an op2 file. OP2INFO /OP2NAMES,UNNAMED/ IUNIT/NAMOPT/S,N,NUMDATBL/S,N,OP2FORM/S,N,BINCOMP/ S,N,USEDVER/S,N,VERSMAJ/S,N,VERSMIN/S,N,VERSSP/ S,N,USEDLAB/S,N,OP2LABEL/S,N,USEDEOF/S,N,USEDKEY/ S,N,KEY/S,N,SCHEMA/S,N,USEDQIB$ OP2NAMES An indexed list of datablocks stored on the op2 file. UNNAMED Not used. May be purged. IUNIT Input-integer-default=0. Fortran unit assigned to op2 file. NAMOPT Input-integer-default=1. Datablock name print options. 0= Do not print names to the F06 file. 1= Print names to the F06 file. NUMDATBL Output-integer-default=0. Number of datablocks on the OP2 file. OP2FORM Output-character-default=blank. The format of the op2 file. NEUTRAL = Neutral, or ASCII, encoded. BIG = 32-bit, big endian. LITTLE = 32-bit, little endian. BIG64 = 64-bit, big endian. LITTLE64 = 64-bit, little endian. BINCOMP Output-logical-default=FALSE. Binary compatibility flag. USEDVER Output-logical-default=FALSE. Versioning information available flag. VERSMAJ Output-character-default=blank. Version Major. VERSMIN Output-character-default=blank. Version Minor. VERSSP Output-character-default=blank. Version Special. USEDLAB Output-logical-default=FALSE. OP2 label available flag.

2339 OP2INFO Retrieves, prints and stores information concerning an op2 file. Main Index Remark: 1.The content of the OP2NAMES datablock may be used to determine if subsequent actions are required or not. Example: OP2INFO /DBNAMES/UNIT/0 $ PARAML DBNAMES//‘DTI2C’/3/4////S,N,NAME2 $OP2LABEL Output-character-default=blank. OP2 label. USEDEOF Output-logical-default=FALSE. EOF marker flag (ITAPE=-9 was set as the last OUTPUT2 data written to the op2 file-see the OUTPUT2 module). USEDKEY Output-logical-default=FALSE. Used KEYs flag (OP2NEW=1 was set when the op2 file was generated). KEY Output-integer-default=0. The value of the last KEY processed. SCHEMA Output-character-default=blank. Datablock schema name. USEDQIB Output-logical-default=FALSE. Qualifier Information (QUALINFO) datablock is present on op2 file (the op2 file was generated with parameter POST set to 1).

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Generates orthonormal set of vectors2340 Main Index Generates an orthonormal set of vectors from a given set of vectors. For example, orthogonalize with respect to an identity matrix or mass matrix. Format: Input Data Blocks: Output Data Blocks: Parameters:ORTHOG Generates orthonormal set of vectors ORTHOG A,M/ Q,R/ ORTHOPT/ORTHCON/S,N,ORTHEPS/ORTHREPT/ORTHTOL $ A Rectangular matrix of m columns (vectors) by n rows to be orthogonalized where m <n. M Weighting matrix: symmetric and positive definite. Q Rectangular matrix of orthogonalized vectors. R Rectangular matrix whose m by m upper triangle contains an intermediate factor of the process. ORTHOPT Input-integer-default=1. Orthogonalization method. 1and M is purged, then perform Householder Orthogonalization. 2or M is not purged, then perform Matrix Modified Gram-Schmidt method. If ORTHOPT=2 and M is purged then an identity matrix will be created for M. ORTHCON Input-integer-default=1. Matrix Modified Gram-Schmidt termination flag or Householder partitioning vector generation flag. For Householder: 0R contains the upper triangular matrix. 1R contains the partitioning vector. For Matrix Modified Gram-Schmidt termination: 0Exit the program if M is not at least a positive semi-definite matrix. R is not used and may be purged. 1Let and continue if is not at least a positive semi-definite matrix. contains the partitioning vector ORTHEPS Output-real-no default. Level of orthogonality. ORTHEPS is the largest lower triangular term of the matrix R and is computed with the Householder method.RiiR–ii= M R

2341 ORTHOG Generates orthonormal set of vectors Main Index Remark: 1.ORTHOG generates an orthonormal set of vectors from a given set of vectors [A] such that: and if ] is not given:
or if is not given:
where is an identity matrix. 2.ORTHOG cannot orthogonalize complex matrices. If a complex matrix is input then a fatal message is issued. SubDMAP ONORM can orthogonalize complex matrices which is described under “General Enhancements for Orthogonalizing Complex Vectors” on page 149 of the MSC Nastran 2004 Release Guide. ORTHREPT Input-real-default=0.707. Matrix Modified Gram-Schmidt algorithm repeat flag. The default is approximately the square root of 0.5. ORTHTOL Input-real-default=0.0. Linear dependence tolerance. By default, ORTHTOL is set to the square root of the minimum machine value. Q A QR = M QTMQ I= M QTQ I= I

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output Frequency Response Result to ADF Format File2342 Main Index Output the frequency response functions and participation factors to ADF format file. Format: Input Data Blocks: Output Data Blocks: Parameters: Remarks: 1.This module support the output table block of OUGx, OSMPF1, OAFMPF1, OASMPF1, OAPMPF1, OAPPF1, OAGPF1 and OSPPF1 (TCODE=1, 10, 11 and 61 to 67). 2.OFPi may be purged. 3.If CASECC is purged, all supported result data in OFPi will output. 4.See the parameter POSTADF for the other information.OUTADF Output Frequency Response Result to ADF Format File OUTADF OFP1,OFP2,OFP3,OFP4,OFP5,UNITS,BGPDT,CASECC//IPRINT $ OFPi Output table suitable for processing. See Remark 2. UNITS T able of units. Usually input by the user via DTI Bulk Data entries. BGPDT Basic grid point definition table. CASECC T able of Case Control command images. See Remark 3. None IPRINT Input-integer-default=0. Message print control flag. If IPRINT<>0, then the detailed output message is printed; 0, otherwise.

item.title: User's Manual P119
item.description:
2343 OUTPRT Constructs sparse load reduction and sparse data recovery partitioning vectors Main Index Constructs partitioning vectors to be used in sparse load reduction and sparse data recovery. Format: Input Data Blocks:OUTPRT Constructs sparse load reduction and sparse data recovery partitioning vectors OUTPRT CASECC,ECT,BGPDT,SIL,XYCDB,DYNAMIC,MATPOOL,PG,VGFD, CASEDS,TABEVP,TABEVS,MMCDB, UNUSED14,UNUSED15, EDT,GPECT, FRFXITZG,FTGID/ PVGRID,PVSPC,PVMPC,PVLOAD,PVMCFR/ S,N,SDRMETH/NOSE/SDROVR/SDRDENS/ UNUSED5/UNUSED6/ MODID$ CASECC Table of Case Control command images. ECT Element connectivity table. BGPDT Basic grid point definition table. SIL Scalar index list. May be purged. XYCDB Table of x-y plotting commands. DYNAMIC Table of Bulk Data entry images related to dynamics. MATPOOL Table of Bulk Data entry images related to hydroelastic boundary, heat transfer radiation, virtual mass, DMIG, and DMIAX entries. PG Static load matrix applied to the g-set. VGFD Partitioning vector with ones at rows corresponding to degrees-of-freedom connected to frequency-dependent elements. CASEDS Case control table for the data recovery of design responses. TABEVP Cross-reference table between ESTDVP records and element and design variable identification numbers. TABEVS Cross reference table between ESTDVS records and element and design variable identification numbers. MMCDB Table of MAXMIN(DEF) specifications. UNUSED14 Unused and may be left blank. UNUSED15 Unused and may be left blank. EDT Table of Bulk Data entry images related to element deformation, aerodynamics, p- element analysis, divergence analysis, and the iterative solver. This module is processes MONPNT3 and SET1 records only. GPECT Table of grid points and associated elements. FRFXITZG Table identifying DOF’s for frequency Response Functions. FTGID Table of elements used in fatigue analysis.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Constructs sparse load reduction and sparse data recovery partitioning vectors2344 Main Index Output Data Blocks: Parameters:PVGRID Partitioning vector with ones at rows corresponding to degrees-of- freedom connected to elements or grids specified on the following Case Control commands: DISPLACEMENT , VELOCITY, ACCELERATION, FORCE, STRESS, STRAIN, SPCFORCE, MPCFORCE, MPRES, GPFORCE, ESE, EKE, EDE, GPKE. PVSPC Partitioning vector with ones at rows corresponding to degrees-of- freedom connected to elements or grids specified on the SPCFORCE Case Control command. PVMPC Partitioning vector with ones at rows corresponding to degrees-of- freedom connected to elements or grids specified on the MPCFORCE Case Control command. PVLOAD Partitioning vector with ones at rows corresponding to degrees-of- freedom at which static and dynamic loads are applied. PVMCFR Partitioning vector with ones at rows corresponding to degrees-of- freedom connected to elements or grids specified on the MCFRACTION Case Control command. SDRMETH Output-integer-no default. Data recovery method flag: -1 Sparse data recovery. 0Full (or standard) data recovery. 1No data recovery is requested or required. NOSE Input-integer-default=0. Set to -1 if there are no superelements; 0 otherwise. Superelement presence flag. SDROVR Input-character-default=‘AUTO’. Override for data recovery method flag, SDR: AUTO Choose full or sparse data recovery based on SDRDENS. FULL Choose full data recovery. SPARSE Choose sparse data recovery. SDRDENS Input-integer-default=0. Sparse data recovery ceiling density. If the density of PVGRID is greater than SDRDENS divided by 100, then choose full data recovery. UNUSED5 Input-integer-default=-1 . Unused and may be left blank. UNUSED6 Input-logical-default=FALSE. Unused and may be left blank. MODID Input-integer-default=0. Module identification number.

2345 OUTPUT2 Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file Main Index Writes a table or matrix data block(s) onto a binary or “compressed ASCII” (or “neutral”) file for user postprocessing or for subsequent input (via INPUTT2) into another MSC Nastran run. Format: Input Data Blocks: Parameters:OUTPUT2 Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file OUTPUT2 DB1,DB2,DB3,DB4,DB5,CASECC// ITAPE/IUNIT/LABL/MAXR/ NDDLNAM1/NDDLNAM2/NDDLNAM3/NDDLNAM4/NDDLNAM5/ HNAME1/HNAME2/HNAME3/HNAME4/HNAME5/PROCID $ DBi Any data block (table or matrix) name to be output. DBi cannot be a factor matrix (forms 4, 5, 10, 11, 13, and 15). Any or all of the input data blocks may be purged. CASECC Table of Case Control command images, specifically for POST command processing. ITAPE Input-integer-default=0. ITAPE is used to select the file positioning option as follows: +n Skip forward n data blocks before writing (only used if file has no label). 0 Data blocks are written starting at the current position. If this is the first use, no label is written. -1 Rewind IUNIT before writing and label file. -3 Rewind IUNIT , print data block names and then write after the last data block on IUNIT (file must have a label). -9 Write a final EOF on IUNIT (must be used before -3 option and as last I/O use of unit) then rewind IUNIT . IUNIT Input-integer-no default. IUNIT is the FORTRAN unit number on which the data blocks are to be written. IUNIT=0 is not recommended. See Remark 7. LABL Input-character-default = ‘XXXXXXXX’. LABL is used for file identification. The label is written only if ITAPE=-1 and is checked only if ITAPE=-3. MAXR Input-integer-default=2 * BUFFS IZE words. Maximum physical record size. (See Remarks.) NDDLNAMi Input-character-default=blank. NDDL names corresponding to DB1 through DB5. If DBi is a matrix, then the corresponding NDDLNAMi is ‘MATRIX’. (See Remarks.)

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file2346 Main Index Remarks: 1.A data block (table or matrix) consists of logical records: In matrices, each column is contained in one logical record. Each record begins with the row position of the first nonzero term in the column followed by the first through the last nonzero term in the column. In tables, the contents of logical records vary according to the table but are described in Data Blocks
(Ch. 2). 2.The FORTRAN binary file consists of physical records of data from the data block and KEYs that are provided to assist in the reading of the file. Each physical record of data is separated by one-word records called KEYs. The KEYs will indicate one of the following depending on its location in the binary file: 3.The End-of-Data (EOD) follows the last end-of-file (data block) written to the binary file. 4.If possible, each logical record of the data block will be written to one physical record of the FORTRAN binary file. However, the length of a logical record may exceed the maximum length of a physical record (see MAXR parameter). If this occurs, then the logical record will span more than one physical record. In other words, the logical record will be written to the first physical record followed by a positive KEY record, which indicates a continuation of the logical record and the length of the subsequent second physical record. 5.The OUTPUT4 module performs similar operations on matrices, but not tables. It is simpler to use and is the recommended method for matrix output. 6.Tables and matrices may be processed as sequential data blocks. 7.The ASSIGN (p.55) in the MSC Nastran Quick Reference Guide FMS statement is recommended for assigning the FORTRAN unit. Selection of a proper value for IUNIT is machine dependent. Refer to the Making File Assignments (p.70) in the MSC Nastran Installation and Operations Guide .HNAMEi Output-character-default=’ ‘. Data block name to written into the header for DBi on the FORTRAN unit. PROCID Input-integer-default=1. Processor ID which is authorized to write to IUNIT . Used only in distributed memory parallel (DMP) runs. KEY Description

0The length of the next physical record. It may also indicate the start of a new logical record. 0 End-of-File (data block) (EOF) or End-of-Data (EOD). <0End-of-Logical record (EOR) or a null column. The absolute value indicates the logical record number.

2347 OUTPUT2 Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file Main Index 8.No physical record will exceed the value specified by the parameter MAXR which has a default that is two times BUFFSIZE words. Furthermore, the value specified for MAXR should not exceed the maximum allowable record size for the receiving disk device. See the Keywords and Environment Variables
in the MSC Nastran Installation and Operations Guide for the maximum allowable values. 9.When the neutral format option is selected via FORM=FORMATTED on the ASSIGN FMS statement (associated with OUTPUT2 parameter IUNIT), then MAXR and NDDLNAMi are interpreted as follows: The following is a partial list of the table data block names available for OUTPUT2 neutral file formatting. For a more complete list see the NDDL. In addition, all matrices defined with a TYPE DB, may also be neutral formatted. If a matrix is not an NDDL data block, then the NDDLNAMi=‘MATRIX’ should be used. For example, to write the matrix MYMATRIX use OUTPUT2 MYMATRIX,,,,//ITAPE/IUNIT/LABL/MAXR/‘MATRIX’ $ Note and the neutral format is a machine-neutral format that allows the transfer of the OUTPUT2- generated files between different machine types. See RCOUT2 (p.215) in the MSC Nastran 2016 Installation and Operations Guide for a discussion of this transfer process and the MSC-supplied conversion utility RCOUT2. 10. The following formats describe each physical record. Note that the following formats depend on the value of system cell 403 (NASTRAN statement keyword OP2NEW).MAXR Represents the maximum physical record size (in words) on the target machine(s) for the machine binary-formatted file after it has been converted from neutral to binary via the MSC-supplied conversion utility RCOUT2. NDDLNAMi Correlates the DMAP data block name with the corresponding NDDL- defined name. If this parameter is left blank, then the corresponding DMAP name (DB1 through DB5) is assumed to be the NDDL-defined name. AXIC GEOM1 GPLS OEIGS OESNL2 OQG2 CASES GEOM1Q LAMA OEP OESNLX OSTR1 CLAMA GEOM2 MATPOOL OES1 OGPWG OSTR2 CSTMS GEOM2S MPT OES1C OGS1 OUGV1 DIT GEOM3 MPTS OES1X OPG1 OUGV2 DYNAMICS GEOM3S OEF1 OES1X1 OPG2 PSDF EPT GEOM4 OEF1X OES2 OPNL1 PVT EPTS GEOM4S OEF2 OESNL1 OQG1 USET FOL GPDTS

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file2348 Main Index Format for Table and Matrix Labels (written only if ITAPE=-1) Format for Tables and Matrices if OP2NEW = 0 ‘Physical Record Number Length Contents Description 1 1 KEY = 3 2 KEY Date (3 words, month-day-year) – integer 3 1 KEY = 7 4 KEYNASTRAN Header (7 words*, Character- A4)One Logical Record *Word 1 = NAST, Word 2 = RAN, Word 3 = FORT , Word 4 = TAP , Word 5=EID, Word 6 = COD, Word 7 = E 5 1 KEY = 2 6 KEY LABEL (2 words, Character-A4 = LABL) If OP2NEW = 0: 7 1 KEY = -1 (EOR) 8 1 KEY = 0 (EOF) End of Label If OP2NEW = 1: 7 1 KEY = 3 8 KEYNastran Program Version (3 words, Major, Minor, Round, Character A4) 9 1 KEY = -1 (EOR) 10 1 KEY = 0 (EOF) Physical Record Number Length Contents Description 9 1 KEY = 2 10 KEY Data Block Name (2 words, Character-A4) Header: Logical. Record1 of Data Block11 1 KEY = -1 (EOR) 12 1 KEY = 7 13 KEY NASTRAN Trailer (7 words, integer) T railer: Logical Record 2 of Data Block 14 1KEY = -2 (EOR) 15 1 KEY = 1 (Start new logical record) 16 1 KEY = 0

2349 OUTPUT2 Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file Main Index Format for Tables and Matrices if OP2NEW = 117 1 KEY = 2. Logical Record 3 of Data Block 18 KEYData Block Name (2 words, Character-A4) and data (if any) 19 1 KEY=-3 (EOR). Physical Record Number Length Contents Description 11 1 KEY = 2 12 KEY Data Block Name (2 words, Character-A4) Header: Logical. Record1 of Data Block13 1 KEY = 3 14 KEYNastran Program Version (3 words, Major, Minor, Round, Character A4) 15 1 KEY = -1 (EOR) 16 1 KEY = 7 17 KEY NASTRAN T railer (7 words, integer) T railer: Logical Record 2 of Data Block 18 1KEY = -2 (EOR) 19 1 KEY = 1 (Start new logical record) 20 1 KEY = 0 21 1 KEY = 2. Logical Record 3 of Data Block 22 KEYData Block Name (2 words, Character-A4) and data (if any) 23 1 KEY=-3 (EOR).Physical Record Number Length Contents Description

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file2350 Main Index Format for Tables (Records 20 through n) Physical Record Number Length Contents DescriptionOP2NEW 0 1 20 24 1 KEY=1 (Start new logical record) Logical Record 4 of Table21 25 KEY Next Logical Record Type=0 for table record 22 26 1 KEY > 0 23 27 KEY Data 24 28 1 KEY < 0 (EOR)** * If more data exists for the column or logical record, then KEY>0 and the physical records 22, 23, and 24 (or 26, 27, and 28) will be repeated as many times as necessary to complete the column or logical record.25 29 1 KEY = 1 (Start new logical record) Logical Record 5 of Table26 30 KEY Next Logical Record Type = 0 27 31 1 KEY > 0 28 32 KEY Data 29 33 1 KEY < 0 (EOR) . . .. . .Repeat Physical Records 25-29 (or 29-33) for Additional Records in TableAdditional Records of Table n-7 1 KEY = 1 (Start new logical record) Last Logical Record of Tablen-6 KEY Next Logical Record Type = 0 n-5 1 KEY > 0 n-4 KEY Data n-3 1 KEY < 0 (EOR)** n-2 1 KEY = 1 (Start new logical record) If Last “Next Logical Record Type" = 0, then End-of-Tablen-1 KEY Next Logical Record Type = 0 n 1 KEY = 0 (EOF)

2351 OUTPUT2 Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file Main Index Format for Matrices (Records 20 or 24 though n) Physical Record Number Length Contents DescriptionOP2NEW 0 1 20 24 1 KEY=1 (Start new logical record) 21 25 KEYNext Logical Record T ype 1 : matrix column (string records) 2 : factor matrix 3 : factor matrix Logical Record 4 of Matrix=first column 22 26 1KEY > 0 Number of non-zero terms in next string in word unitFirst Column First String Record 23 27 KEY+1First non-zero row, followed by non-zero terms 24 28 1KEY > 0 Number of non-zero terms in next string in word unitFirst Column Second String Record 25 29 KEY+1First non-zero row, followed by non-zero terms. Repeat String Records 22-23 for Additional Strings in Column n-2 1KEY > 0 Number of non-zero terms in next string in word unitFirst Column Last String Record n-1 KEY+1First non-zero row, followed by non-zero terms. n 1 KEY<0 (EOR) End of First Column Repeat Column/String Records 20 through n for additional columns in matrix if a column is null there is no String Record for that column n 1 KEY=1 (Start new logical record) Null Column

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file2352 Main Index Format for Tables and Matrix-End-of-Data 11. OUTPUT2 files may be read using three utility subroutines provided in the utility (“util”) directory; see Building and Using TABTST (p.248) in the MSC Nastran 2016 Utilities Guide . These routines in a file called tabtst.f (or.for) . These routines are coded in machine-independent FORTRAN. Major benefits that result in using this standard interface are: Easier initial usage of OUTPUT2. Most users make several errors while becoming familiar with the formats. User code is not burdened/concerned with physical record boundaries. Data can be processed in logical groups rather than in a “blast” read mode. Major limitations include: Matrices cannot be processed in this manner.Physical Record Number Length Contents Description n+1 KEYNext Logical Record Type (See Record 21 above) n+2 1 KEY<0 (EOR) End of Null Column m-5 1KEY > 0 Number of non-zero terms in next string in word unitLast Column Last String Record m-4 KEY+1First non-zero row, followed by non-zero terms m-3 1 KEY<0 End of Last Column m-2 1 KEY=1 (Start new logical record)TD> m-1 KEYNext Logical Record type=0 If Last “Next Logical Record T ype” = 0 m 1 KEY = 0 (EOF) End of Matrix Physical Record Number Length Contents n + 1 1 If No Data Blocks Follow, KEY = 0 (EOD) End-of-Data IOPEN Once per FORTRAN unit. IHEADR Once per data block. IREAD As many times as desired.

2353 OUTPUT2 Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file Main Index Multiple FORTRAN units cannot be simultaneously processed. BACKSPACE operations are not permitted. Following are descriptions and use of the three OUTPUT2 service routines. 12. Starting with MSC Nastran 2004 the OUTPUT2 file transport format has been enhanced to better delineate the content to allow external applications to identify version and stride values for IFP class datablocks. The new MSC Nastran keyword for either the NASTRAN statement or RC file inclusion is OP2NEW and is linked to system cell 403. This is an integer value with a default of one (1), Entry Point Description IOPENInitializes an OUTPUT2 file and read the label (MSC Nastran). Format: CALL IOPEN(IUN,L) where IUN = An input integer which specifies the unit number to be read. L = An output two-word array (2A4) containing the label written on the unit (L comes from the third parameter in the DMAP call). Method: IOPEN rewinds IUN and reads in the data, title, and label. The keys are checked. A key check failure results in the message IOPEN BAD KEYX = XXXX. IHEADRProcesses the data block name and trailer. Format: CALL IHEADR(IUN,NAM,T) where IUN = As described in IOPEN. NAM = An output two-word array (2A4) containing the data block trailer in words two through seven. Word one contains the location in the DMAP call (101,102, etc.) Method: IHEADR reads the name and trailer. It checks KEY lengths. It also skips the data block header (which unfortunately may contain data for some/few data blocks). IHEADR must be called for each data block either immediately after IOPEN or after IREAD signifies an end-of-file.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output a table or matrix into a FORTRAN readable file2354 Main Index indicating that the new transport format is used. A value of zero (0) removes all version information and IFP locate word changes from the transport file. Modification for version occurs both in the Label Record and within the Data Block Name record. For more details, see Modifications to OUTPUT2 (INPUTT2) Transport Formats in the MSC.Nastran 2004 Release Guide . 13. When Case Control command, RANDOUT, is requested for PSDF-only OP2, only PSDF related OFP tables are written to OP2. Any other solution results are ignored and skipped by OUTPUT2.Entry Point Description IREADSupplies data to the calling program in a logical (as opposed to a physical) manner. Format: CALL IREAD(IUN,ARRY,NARY,IMETH,NT,IRTN) where IUN is as described in IOPEN. ARRY is the array into which a record is transmitted. NARY is an integer input that requests the number of words to be transmitted. If NARY is zero, no words will be transmitted. If NARY is negative, the words will be skipped but not transmitted. If (NARY is greater than the number of words remaining, the remaining words are processed (skipped or transmitted) and NT is set to this number and IRTN is set to 1. IMETH is an integer input that specifies how to proceed through the logical record. If IMETH = 0, the current logical record is continuously processed until an end-of- record return (IRTN =1) is given. If IMETH = 1, the remaining data (if any) at the conclusion of IREAD, in the current logical record, is skipped. NT is an integer output value which contains the number of words transmitted or skipped if IRTN is 1 on return from IREAD. IRTN is an integer output value which indicates the status on return from IREAD. IRTN = 0 Normal return. IRTN = 1 End of logical record hit while trying to process NARY words. IRTN = 2 End-of-file hit for this data block. Method: OUTPUT2 physical records are read into a buffer area. These records are, at most, 2 * BUFFSIZE words long. The current position is maintained and data is transmitted (or skipped) from the buffer to the ARRY array. If the MSC Nastran logical record spans several physical FORTRAN records these are transparent (no end-of-record returns) to the user.

2355 OUTPUT4 Output matrices onto a FORTRAN readable file Main Index Write matrices in ASCII or binary format onto a FORTRAN readable file. Format: Input Data Blocks: Parameters:OUTPUT4 Output matrices onto a FORTRAN readable file OUTPUT4 M1,M2,M3,M4,M5//ITAPE/IUNIT/UNUSED3/BIGMAT/DIGITS/ HNAME1/HNAME2/HNAME3/HNAME4/HNAME5 $ Mi Matrices. Mi cannot be a factor matrix (forms 4, 5, 10, 11, 13, and 15). ITAPE Input-integer-default = -1. ITAPE controls the status of the unit before OUTPUT4 starts to write any matrices as follows: ITAPE ACTION 0 None. -1 Rewind IUNIT before Write. -2 End File and Rewind IUNIT after Write. -3 Both. IUNIT Input-integer-no default. The absolute value of IUNIT is the FORTRAN unit number on which the matrices will be written. If IUNIT is negative, the sparse output option will be used, which means only nonzero items in the matrix are written to the unit. IUNIT = 0 is not recommended. See Remark 1 . UNUSED3 Input-integer-default=1. Unused.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output matrices onto a FORTRAN readable file2356 Main Index Remarks: 1.Each matrix will be written on IUNIT as follows: Record 1:BIGMAT Input-logical-default=FALSE. BIGMAT is applicable only when IUNIT < 0. BIGMAT=FALSE selects the format that uses a string header as described under Remark 1. But, if the matrix has more than 65535 rows, then BIGMAT will automatically be set to TRUE regardless of the value specified. DIGITS Input-integer-default = 9. DIGITS is the requested number of digits for the fractional part of the real values written for the ASCII format option (FORMATTED on the ASSIGN FMS statement). The FORTRAN Format Specification used internally by OUTPUT4 to write real values will be formed as follows: FORTRAN Format Specification: P ,rEw.d d = DIGITS w = d + 7 r = 80/w (integer portion) For example, if DIGITS = 9 then the format will be 1P,5E16.9 or if DIGITS = 16 then the format will be 1P,3E23.16 HNAMEi Input-character-default=’ ‘. Data block name to be written to the header for DBi on the FORTRAN unit. By default, the DMAP data block name will be written to the header. Word Number Type Meaning 1 Integer Number of columns (NCOL). 2 Integer Number of rows (NR, if BIGMAT=TRUE then NR < 0). 3 Integer Form of matrix (NF). See Remark 11. 4 Integer Type of matrix (NTYPE). See Remark 11. 5 and 6 Character Name of matrix (2A4 format). 7 CharacterIf ASCII format, then this is the FORTRAN format specification based on DIGITS parameter value. If binary format, then this is blank. 8 CharacterIf binary format, this is blank. If ASCII format, and if the field of NCOL or NROW exceeds 8 digits, this is “|I16”, and the first two integers NCOL and NROW are written in Fortran “2I16” format. If fields of NCOL and NROW are within 8 digits, this is blank.

2357 OUTPUT4 Output matrices onto a FORTRAN readable file Main Index Records 2, 3, 4, etc. for nonsparse and binary format, (IUNIT > 0 and binary format) and repeated for each nonzero column, i=ICOL through NCOL. Records 2, 3, 4, etc. for nonsparse and ASCII format, (IUNIT > 0), are repeated for each nonzero column, ICOL through NCOL. Records 3, 4, etc., are also repeated for each group of r values (see DIGITS parameter). Records 2, 3, 4, etc. for sparse, binary, and string header format (IUNIT < 0, and BIGMAT = FALSE).Word Number Type Meaning 1 Integer Column number (ICOL). 2 Integer Row position of first nonzero term (IROW). 3 IntegerNumber of words (for binary) or terms (for ascii) in the column (NW). See Remark 3. 4 through (NW+3)Real or ComplexColumn element values, single or double precision. Record NumberWord Number Type Meaning 2 1 Integer Column number (ICOL). 2 IntegerRow position of first nonzero term (IROW). 3 IntegerNumber of words (for binary) or terms (for ascii) in the column (NW). See Remark 3. 3, 4, etc. 1 through NW Real or ComplexColumn element values, single or double precision. Word Number Type Meaning 1 Integer Column number (ICOL). 2 Integer Zero. 3 Integer Number of words in the column (NW). See Remark 3. 4 through (NW+3)Integer String header (IS)*. Real or ComplexA string of nonzero values, single or double precision.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output matrices onto a FORTRAN readable file2358 Main Index IS = IROW + 65536(L + 1) where IROW is the row position of the first term in the string and L is the length of the string, see Remark 3 . For example, a string of six words (see Remark 3) beginning in row 4 has IS=458756. L and IROW may be derived from IS by: L = INT(IS/65536) - 1 IROW = IS - 65536(L + 1) Records 2, 3, 4, etc. for sparse, binary, and regular string format (IUNIT < 0, and BIGMAT = TRUE). Records 2, 3, 4, etc. for sparse, ASCII, and string header format (IUNIT < 0, and BIGMAT = FALSE) are repeated for each nonzero column. Records 3 and 4 are repeated for each string, and record 4 is also repeated for each group of r values (see DIGITS parameter). Records 2, 3, 4, etc. for sparse, ASCII, and regular string format (IUNIT < 0, and BIGMAT = TRUE) are repeated for each nonzero column. Records 3 and 4 are repeated for each string and record 4 is also repeated for each group of r values (see DIGITS parameter).Word Number Type Meaning 1 Integer Column number (ICOL). 2 Integer Zero. 3 IntegerNumber of words in the column (NW). See Remark 3. 4 through (NW+3)Integer Length of string, L, plus 1. See Remark 3. Repeated for each string.Integer Row position of first term in string (IROW). Real or complexA string of nonzero values, single or double precision. Record NumberWord Number Type Meaning 21 Integer Column number (ICOL). 2 Integer Zero. 3 IntegerNumber of words in the column (NW). See Remark 3. 3 1 Integer String header (IS). 4 1 through NW Real or ComplexA string of nonzero values, single or double precision.

2359 OUTPUT4 Output matrices onto a FORTRAN readable file Main Index 2.A record with the last column number plus +1 and at least one value in the next record will be written on IUNIT. 3.The number of words in the column, NW (or string, L), is the number of elements in the column (or string) times the number of words per type. Number of words per type is given in the table below. For example, a column with seven real double precision elements is 14 words long. 4.The ASSIGN FMS statement is recommended for assigning the FORTRAN unit (see the MSC Nastran Quick Reference Guide ). Selection of a proper value for IUNlT is machine dependent. See Making File Assignments (p.70) in the MSC Nastran Installation and Operations Guide . 5.If the nonsparse format (IUNIT > 0) is selected, zero terms will be explicitly present after the first nonzero term in any column until the last nonzero term. 6.Null columns will not be output. 7.An entire column must fit in memory. 8.The FORTRAN binary file option (FORM = UNFORMATTED on the ASSIGN FMS statement) is the preferred method when the file is to be used on the same computer. The ASCII format FORM = UNFORMATTED on the ASSIGN FMS statement allows use of the file on another computer type. 9.The output format of these files can be read by the INPUTT4 module.Record NumberWord Number Type Meaning 21 Integer Column number (ICOL). 2 Integer Zero. 3 IntegerNumber of words in the column (NW). See Remark 3. 31 Integer Length of string, L, plus 1. See Remark 3. 2 IntegerRow position of first term in string (IROW). 4 1 through NWReal or ComplexA string of nonzero values, single or double precision. Type Number of Words 1 – Real single precision 1 2 – Real double precision 2 3 – Complex single precision 2 4 – Complex double precision 4

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Output matrices onto a FORTRAN readable file2360 Main Index 10. OUTPUT4 files may be read using a utility FORTRAN subroutine called GETIDS, which is provided in the utility directory. (See Building and Using MATTST (p.242) in the MSC Nastran 2016 Utilities Guide .) GETIDS is in the file called mattst.f or mattst.for. The program must be modified if the ASCII format is desired. The program is designed to read matrices less than 65536 rows. (BIGMAT = FALSE). 11. Sparse factor matrices (forms 4, 5, 10, 11, 13, and 15) cannot be processed by OUTPUT4.

2361 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Sets parameters from a data block. Format: Input Data Block: Output Data Block: Parameters: The following describes the various options and their formats. The meaning and usage of parameters P2 through P6, SETi, and Fi depend on the value of P1. Under all options P5 will be set to -1, if the input data block does not exist, and no other parameters will be set.PARAML Sets parameters from a data block PARAML DB/DBNAME/P1/S,N,P2/S,N,P3/S,N,P4/S,N,P5/S,N,P6/ S,N,SET1/S,N,F1/S,N,SET2/S,N,F2/ S,N,SET3/S,N,F3/S,N,SET4/S,N,F4/ S,N,SET5/S,N,F5/S,N,SET6/S,N,F6/ S,N,SET7/S,N,F7/S,N,SET8/S,N,F8/ S,N,SET9/S,N,F9/S,N,SET10/S,N,F10/ S,N,SET11/S,N,F11/S,N,SET12/S,N,F12 $ DB Any matrix or table. DBNAME Any data block. Used only when P1 = ‘NAME’; otherwise DBname must not be specified. P1 Input -character -no default. Only the first 4 characters are required except for options beginning with ’DTI2’, ’COMP’, ’TABI’, and ’TABR’. For example, ‘PRES’ and ‘PRESENCE’ are equivalent. P2 Input/output -integer -default = 1. P3 Input/output -integer -default = 1. P4 Output -real-default = 0.0. P5 Output -integer -default = 0. P6 Output -real-default = 0.0. SETi Input/output -character -default = ’ ‘. Fi Output -integer -default = 0.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2362 Main Index List of Options P1 Description Option P1 = ‘BLKNAM’ Given a record number in an IFP table extract its Bulk Entry name. Option P1 = ‘BLKPOS’ Get position of a bulk data entry from an IFP table. Option P1 = ‘BULK’ Check for the presence of Bulk Data entry records by examining the trailer bits of its IFP module related table. Option P1=’COMPVEND’, ‘COMPMODL’, ‘COMPOS’, and ‘COMPOS1’Extract the computer and operating system information. Option P1 = ‘DBSET’ T est for the presence of DBset(s). Option P1 = ‘DMI’ Extract an element from a matrix. Option P1 = ‘DTI’ Extract a real, integer, complex, or character value from a table. Option P1 = ‘DTI2’ Extract double precision load factor stored in two consecutive words of the ESTNL data block and truncate to single precision. Option P1 = ‘DTI2C’ Extract character value stored in two consecutive words. Option P1=‘EXTBULK’ Extract a record from an IFP table; e.g., MAT1 record from MPT table . Option P1=‘HEAD’ Given a Bulk Data entry’s name extract its header words, instance length, and number of instances. Option P1 = ‘IMATCH’ Search for a specific integer value in a table record. Option P1 = ‘NAME’ Return the name and purge status of a data block. Option P1 = ‘NULL’ T est for a null or full matrix. Option P1=‘PARAM’ T est for the presence (existence) of a data block. Option P1 = ‘PRESENCE’ T est for the presence (existence) of a data block. Option P1=‘SET’ Extract elements of a SET defined in Case Control. Option P1=‘TABDEL’ Delete a group of words in a record, the trailing portion of a record, or the entire record in a table. Option P1=‘TABINSR’, ‘TABINSI’, ‘TABINSC’, and ‘TABINS2C’Insert a new value in a record or insert a new record after an existing record in a table. Option P1=‘TABREPR’, ‘TABREPI’, ‘TABREPC’, and ‘TABREP2C’Replace any value in any record of a table. Option P1 = ‘TRAILER’ Extract a value from the trailer of a data block or set information from USET.

item.title: User's Manual P12
item.description:
203 CYCD Connectivity of degrees of freedom Main Index In the analysis set [Ua] for real eigenvalue analysis, or [Ud] for dynamic analysis by the direct method. This table can be created under three different symmetry options: Rotational, Dihedral and Axial. Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - DOFSET Record 3 - SILSET Record 4 - TRAILER CYCD Connectivity of degrees of freedom Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 DOF I CYCD value per dof in the analysis set Word 1 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 KOUNT I number of dof supported for the CYSUP point 2 DOF I 3 SILORSYS I SILA number or Coordinate System T ype Words 2 through 3 repeat until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 ITYP I 1=> Rotational option2=> Dihedral option 3=> Axial option 2 NDOFA I number of degrees of freedom in the analysis set 3 NSUP I number of degrees of freedom for the CYSUP point 4 WORD4 I Not used 5 WORD5 I Not used 6 WORD6 I Not used

CYCD Connectivity of degrees of freedom204 Main Index Notes: 1.CYCD is based on the grid point location. 2.SILSET entry repeats for each supported DOF on the CYSUP point. 3.Coordinate System Type is obtained from the CYJOIN Bulk Entry. (field 3) and is coded as follows T1 ) = 1, T2, R, or C) = 2, T3, or S ) = 3 “Blank” ) = 0. 4.CYCD Values for the Rotational Case

Location of Grid Point DOF CYCD

Interior all 0 Side 1 all SILA of conn

  •                                    DOF on side2

Side 2 all -1 Axis T1 -2

  •                       T2           -3

  •                       T3 -4

  •                       R1           -5

  •                       R2           -6

  •                       R3           -7

5.CYCD Values for the Dihedral Case

Location of Grid Point DOF CYCD

Side 1 even 1

  •                        odd 2

Side 2 even 3

  • odd 4 Interior all 0 Axis T1 5
  •                       T2 6

  •                       T3 7

  •                       R1 8

  •                       R2 9

  •                       R3 10

205 CYCD Connectivity of degrees of freedom Main Index Notes: 6.Even/Odd Definition Table

Code: 1 = grid point; 2 = scalar point Code Coordinate DOF Even/Odd

  •  System

  •  Type

1 0 all fatal error 1 1 2,3,4 even

  •                 1,5,6   odd

1 2 1,3,5 even

  •                 2,4,6   odd

1 3 1,2,6 even

  •                 3,4,5   odd

2 0 all even 2 1 all odd 2 2 all even 2 3 all even *Code: 1 = grid point; 2 = scalar point 7.CYCD values for the Axial Case

Location of Grid Point DOF CYCD

Interior all fatal error Side 1 all SILA of conn

  •                                    DOF on side2

  •                                    + offset*

Side 2 all -1 Axis T1 -2+offset

  •                       T2           -3+offset

  •                       T3           -4

  •                       R1           -5+offset

  •                       R2           -6+offset

  •                       R3           -7

*The values of the offset depend on the even/odd factor for side 1, points and the dot number for axis points. The following table gives the offset values. 8.Grid Location Even/Odd Offset

Side 1 even 15,000,000

  •          odd        0

Axis -10

DBCOPT Design optimization history table for postprocessing206 Main Index Record 1 – HEADER Record 2 – EXACT Record 3 – APPRX Record 4 – MAXIM Record 5 – DVIDS Record 6 – INITVDBCOPT Design optimization history table for postprocessing Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Data Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 REAL RS Objective function values, exact from analysis Word 1 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 REAL RS Objective function values, optimal w.r.t approximation Word 1 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 REAL RS Objective function values, maximum values of constraints Word 1 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 INTGR I Design variable identification number Word 1 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 REAL RS Design variable values, 1st cycle ? Word 1 repeats until End of Record

207 DEFUSET Design optimization history table for postprocessing Main Index Record 7 Record 6 – COL17 Record 8 – DVLABEL Record 9 – TRAILER DEFUSETWord Name Type Description 1 REAL RS Design variable value, Nth cycle ? Word 1 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 IDVID I Internal design variable identification number 2 DVID I External design variable identification number 3 LABEL1 CHAR4 First part of design variable 4 LABEL2 CHAR4 Second part of design variable Word Name Type Description 1 NFEA I Number of finite element analyses 2 NAOP I Number of optimization cycles with respect to approximate model 3 NDV I Number of design variables 4 NCC I Convergence criterion 5 UNDEF(2 ) none Not used Notes: 1.Convergence criterion: 1 = Hard convergence 2 = Soft convergence 3 = Compromise 4 = Maximum design cycles reached

DEFUSET Design optimization history table for postprocessing208 Main Index Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - DEFUSET Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Word Name Type Description 1 UM I 2 UO I 3 UR I 4 USG I 5 USB I 6 UL I 7 UA I 8 UF I 9 US I 10 UN I 11 UG I 12 UE I 13 UP I 14 UNE I 15 UFE I 16 UD I 17 UPS I 18 USA I 19 UK I 20 UPA I 21 UQ I 22 UB I 23 UC I 24 UT I 25 UFR I 26 UV I 27 U27 I

209 DEFUSET Design optimization history table for postprocessing Main Index Record 3 - TRAILER 28 U28 I 29 U29 I 30 U30 I 31 U31 I 32 U32 I 33 BITNAME(32) CHAR4 Word Name Type Description 1 WORD1 I 2 WORD2 I 3 WORD3 I 4 WORD4 I 5 WORD5 I 6 WORD6 I Word Name Type Description

DEQATN User supplied equations210 Main Index Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - Repeat DEQATN User supplied equations Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 RC I Record count 2 ARGS I Number of arguments 3 OSCAR I Oscar type (13) 4 DEQA CHAR4 BCD 5 RECNUM I Record number 6 BIT I ID number V bit32 7 TLC(C) I Temp VPS location count 8 TEMPVPS I Temp VPS locations Word 8 repeats TLC times 9 IC(C) I Instruction word count (x 4) (BCD;I;I;I ) 10 INST I Instruction Word 10 repeats IC times 11 TEMP VPS I TEMP VPS=1 12 INT I Integer TEMP VPS=2 12 REAL RS Real TEMP VPS=3 12 BCD(2) CHAR4 Character TEMP VPS=4 12 REALMACH RX Real machine precision End TEMP VPS VAL
Words 11 through max repeat until End of Record

211 DEQATN User supplied equations Main Index Record 3 - TRAILER Word Name Type Description 1 WORD1 I 2 WORD2 I 3 WORD3 I 4 WORD4 I 5 WORD5 I 6 WORD6 I

DEQIND Disk address of DEQATN indexed by EQID.212 Main Index Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - INDEX Record 3 - TRAILER DEQIND Disk address of DEQATN indexed by EQID. Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 EQID I Equation id 2 FILPOS(4) I disk address pointer Words 1 through 5 repeat until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 WORD1 I 2 WORD2 I 3 WORD3 I 4 WORD4 I 5 WORD5 I 6 WORD6 I

213 DESELM Designed elements. Main Index Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - Repeat Record 3 - TRAILER DESELM Designed elements. Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Data Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 EID I Element ID 2 PID I Property ID 3 LAYER I Composite ply ID 4 PLOC I Location in PROPI Word Name Type Description 1 NEID I Number of designed elements 2 MXLOC I Maximum location in PROPI 3 UNDEF(4 ) none

DESGID Designed SIL attributes214 Main Index Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - HEADER Record 3 - TRAILERDESGID Designed SIL attributes Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 GRIDID I Grid ID 2 SILID I SIL ID 3 INTID I Internal ID 4 COMP I Component (1,2 or 3) Words 1 through 4 repeat until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 NSIL I Number of designed SILS 2 WORD2 I not defined 3 WORD3 I not defined 4 WORD4 I not defined 5 WORD5 I not defined 6 WORD6 I not defined

215 DESGID68 Designed SIL attributes - Version 68 format Main Index Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - HEADER Record 3 - TRAILER DESGID68 Designed SIL attributes - Version 68 format Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 GRIDID I Grid ID 2 SILID I SIL ID 3 COMP I Component (1,2 or 3) Words 1 through 3 repeat until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 NSIL I Number of designed SILS 2 WORD2 I not defined 3 WORD3 I not defined 4 WORD4 I not defined 5 WORD5 I not defined 6 WORD6 I not defined

DESTAB Design variable attributes216 Main Index Record 1 – HEADER Record 2 – Repeat Record 3 – TRAILERDESTAB Design variable attributes Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Data block name Word Name Type Description 1 IDVID I Internal design variable identification number 2 DVID I External design variable identification number 3 LABEL1 CHAR4 First part of design variable 4 LABEL2 CHAR4 Second part of design variable 5 VMIN RS Lower bound 6 VMAX RS Upper bound 7 DELX RS Move limit for a design cycle Word Name Type Description 1 NDV I Number of design variables 2 NDVI I Number of independent design variables 3 NDVD I Number of dependent design variables 4 UNDEF(3 ) none Not used Note: 1.Independent design variables are given first in ascending IDVID followed by dependent design variables in ascending IDVID order.

217 DFFDNF Frequency Response Sensitivity List Main Index Contains one logical record for each different frequency set defined in the Bulk Data. Each record contains the set ID and entries of seven words. Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - Repeat Record 3 - TRAILER DFFDNF Frequency Response Sensitivity List Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Data Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 FQSETID I FREQUENCY SET ID 2 FORFRQ RS Forcing frequency 3 NFRQID1 I Natural frequency 1 ID 4 NFEQVAL1 RS Natural Frequency 1 value 5 SENSIT1 RS Sensitivity 1 6 NFRQID2 I Natural frequency 2 ID 7 NFEQVAL2 RS Natural frequency 2 value 8 SENSIT2 RS Sensitivity 2 Words 2 through 8 repeat until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 WORD1 I Number of frequency sets 2 UNDEF(5 ) none

DISTAB Discrete Value Set218 Main Index Record 1 - HEADER Record 2 - Repeat Record 3 - TRAILER DISTAB Discrete Value Set Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Data Block Name Word Name Type Description 1 IDVID I Discrete value set identification number 2 DVALI RS real discrete values Word 2 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 NDVSET I Number of discrete value set 2 MAXRL I Maximum record length 3 UNDEF(4 ) none

219 DIT Direct input tables Main Index Contains images of TABLEij, TABDMP1 and GUST Bulk Data entries. Record 1 – HEADER Record 2 – GUST(1005,10,174) Record 3 – TABDMP1(15,21,162) Record 4 – TABLE3D(4000,40,460)DIT Direct input tables Word Name Type Description 1 NAME(2) CHAR4 Data block name Word Name Type Description 1 SID I Gust load identification number 2 DLOAD I TLOADi or RLOADi identification number 3 WG RS Scale factor 4 X0 RS Streamwise location of the gust reference point 5 V RS Velocity of vehicle Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 UNDEF(7 ) none Not used 9 F RS Natural frequency 10 G RS Damping Words 9 through 10 repeat until (-1,-1) occurs Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 X0 RS X offset of the independent variable 3 Y0 RS Y offset of the independent variable 4 Z0 RS Z offset of the independent variable 5 F0 RS Offset of the dependent variable 6 UNDEF(3 ) none Not used 9 XI RS X independent variable

DIT Direct input tables220 Main Index Record 5 – TABLED1(1105,11,133) Record 6 – TABLED2(1205,12,134) Record 7 – TABLED3(1305,13,140)10 YI RS Y independent variable 11 ZI RS Z independent variable 12 FI RS Dependent variable Words 9 through 12 repeat until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 CODEX I Type of interpolation for the x-axis 3 CODEY I Type of interpolation for the y-axis 4 UNDEF(5 ) none Not used 9 X RS X tabular value 10 Y RS Y tabular value Words 9 through 10 repeat until (-1,-1) occurs Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 X1 RS X-axis shift 3 UNDEF(6 ) none Not used 9 X RS X value 10 Y RS Y value Words 9 through 10 repeat until (-1,-1) occurs Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 X1 RS X-axis shift 3 X2 RS X-axis normalization 4 UNDEF(5 ) none Not usedWord Name Type Description

221 DIT Direct input tables Main Index Record 8 – TABLED4(1405,14,141) Record 9 – TABLEDR(4201,42,648) Record 10 – TABLEM1(105,1,93) Same as record TABLED1 description ( page 220). Record 11 – TABLEM2(205,2,94) Same as record TABLED2 description ( page 220). Record 12 – TABLEM3(305,3,95) Same as record TABLED3 description ( page 221). Record 13 – TABLEM4(405,4,96) Same as record TABLED4 description ( page 221).9 X RS X value 10 Y RS Y value Words 9 through 10 repeat until (-1,-1) occurs Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 X1 RS X-axis shift 3 X2 RS X-axis normalization 4 X3 RS X value when x is less than X3 5 X4 RS X value when x is greater than X4 6 UNDEF(3 ) none Not used 9 A RS Word 9 repeats until End of Record Word Name Type Description 1 TIB I Table rate identification number
2 VALUE RS Value related to the following TABLED1 identification number
3 TBID I TABLED1 identification number
Words 2 through 3 repeat until End of Record Word Name Type Description

DIT Direct input tables222 Main Index Record 13 – TABLES1(3105,31,97) Record 14 – TABLEST(1905,19,178) Record 15 – TABRND1(55,25,191) Record 16 – TABRNDG(56,26,303) Power spectral density for gust loads in aeroelastic analysis. Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 UNDEF(7 ) none Not used 9 X RS X value 10 Y RS Y value Words 9 through 10 repeat until (-1,-1) occurs Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 UNDEF(7 ) none Not used 9 TI RS T emperature 10 TIDI I TABLES1 Bulk Data entry identification number Words 9 through 10 repeat until (-1,-1) occurs Word Name Type Description 1 ID I T able identification number 2 CODEX I T ype of interpolation for the x-axis 3 CODEY I T ype of interpolation for the y-axis 4 UNDEF(5 ) none Not used 9 F RS Frequency 10 G RS Power spectral density Words 9 through 10 repeat until (-1,-1) occurs Word Name Type Description 1 ID I Table identification number 2 TYPE I Power spectral density type 3 LU RS Scale of turbulence divided by velocity

item.title: User's Manual P120
item.description:
2363 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Option P1 = ‘BLKNAM’ Given a record number in an IFP table extract its Bulk Entry name. Format: Input Data Block: Output D ata Block: None. Parameters: Example: Extract Bulk Data entry name for record number 4 in the GEOM4 table. PARAML GEOM4//‘BLKNAM’/4/S,N,P3////S,N,BLKNAM $ Option P1 = ‘BLKPOS’ Get record position of a bulk data entry from an IFP table. Format:Option P1 = ‘USET’ Search for a specific integer value in a table record. Option P1=’VERSID’, ‘VERSID1’, ‘VERSID2’, ‘VERSID3’, ‘VERSID4’, and ‘VERSDATE’Extract the program version information as shown in f06 title page banner.
Option P1=‘XYCDB’ Check for the presence of a response types specified on xy plotting commands: XYPAPLOT, XYPEAK, XYPLOT , XYPRINT and XYPUNCH. PARAML IFPDB//‘BLKNAM’/IRECNO/S,N,P3////S,N,BLKNAM IFPDB IFP table. For example, GEOM1, MPT , etc. IRECNO Input-integer. Record number in IFPDB to extract Bulk Data entry’s name P3 Output-integer. Set to -1 if entry name cannot be determined BLKNAM Output-character. Name of Bulk Data entry. PARAML IFPDB//‘BLKPOS’//////RECNAM/S,N,RECPOSP1 Description

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2364 Main Index Input Data Block: Output Data Block: None. Parameters: Example: Extract Bulk Data entry record position for “BCONECT” in the contact table. PARAML CONTACT//‘BLKPOS’//////‘BCONECT ‘/S,N,RECPOS $ Option P1 = ‘BULK’ Check for the presence of Bulk Data entry records by examining the trailer bits of its IFP module related table. Format: Input Data Block: Parameters: Remark: To determine which table contains BULKNMi, see Data Blocks (Ch. 2). Example: Check for the presence of the rigid elements.IFPDB IFP datablock contains the bulk data entry. RECNAM Input-character-no default RECPOS Output-integer-default=0; record position, 0 when not found PARAML IFPDB//‘BULK’////// BULKNM1/S,N,BULKFG1/BULKNM2/S,N,BULKFG2/ BULKNM3/S,N,BULKFG3/BULKNM4/S,N,BULKFG4/ BULKNM5/S,N,BULKFG5/BULKNM6/S,N,BULKFG6/ BULKNM7/S,N,BULKFG7/BULKNM8/S,N,BULKFG8/ BULKNM9/S,N,BULKFG9/BULKNM10/S,N,BULKFG10/ BULKNM11/S,N,BULKFG11/BULKNM12/S,N,BULKFG12 $ IFPDB T able with trailer bits indicating existence of Bulk Data entry records. BULKNMi Input-character. Name of Bulk Data entry. BULKFGi Output-integer. Set to -1 if Bulk Data entry exists.

2365 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Option P1=’COMPVEND’, ‘COMPMODL’, ‘COMPOS’, and ‘COMPOS1’ Extract the computer and operating system information. Formats: Extract the computer’s vendor name: Extract the computer’s model name: Extract the computer’s operating system: Extract any additional operating system information: Input Data Blocks: None. Output Data Blocks: None. Parameter: : Remarks:

  1. The CHARi values may be best displayed with: MESSAGE //CHAR1/CHAR2/CHAR3/CHAR4 $PARAML GEOM4//‘BULK’//////‘RBE1’/S,N,RBE1/‘RBE2’/S,N,RBE2/ ‘RBE3’/S,N,RBE3/‘RROD’/S,N,RROD/‘RBAR’/S,N,RBAR/ ‘RTRPLT’/S,N,RTRPLT/‘RSPLINE’/S,N,RSPLINE $ PARAML //’COMPVEND’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ PARAML //’COMPMODL’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ PARAML //’COMPOS ’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ PARAML //’COMPOS1 ’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ CHARi Output-character. Up to 32 characters are extracted into CHARi the values which when concatenated form the complete label.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2366 Main Index Option P1 = ‘DBSET’ Detect the presence of DBset(s). Format: Input Data Blocks: Output Data Blocks: Parameters: Example: Test the presence of DBset named MYDBSET: PARAML //‘DBSET’/1/////’MYDBSET’/S,N,DBSNO $ Option P1 = ‘DMI’ Extract an element from a matrix. Format: Input Data Block:PARAML //‘DBSET’/DBSNO///// DBSNAM1/S,N,DBSNUM1/DBSNAM2/S,N,DBSNUM2/ DBSNAM3/S,N,DBSNUM3/DBSNAM4/S,N,DBSNUM4/ DBSNAM5/S,N,DBSNUM5/DBSNAM6/S,N,DBSNUM6/ DBSNAM7/S,N,DBSNUM7/DBSNAM8/S,N,DBSNUM8/
DBSNAM9/S,N,DBSNUM9/DBSNAM10/S,N,DBSNUM10/
DBSNAM11/S,N,DBSNUM11/DBSNAM12/S,N,DBSNUM12 $ None. None. DBSNO Input-integer. Database number. Usually “1” for primary database and “2” for delivery database. “3” or greater indicates DBLOCATE’d databases. DBSNAMi Input-character. DBset name. DBSNUMi Output-integer. DBset number. Set to 0 if the DBset does not exist. PARAML MAT//’DMI’/ICOL/IROW/S,N,REAL/ S,N,NROW/S,N,IMAG $ MAT Any matrix. (Real or complex).

2367 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Parameters: Remark: 1.If IROW is greater than the number of rows in the matrix, then NROW will be set to the number of rows and REAL and IMAG will be set to zero. Example: Obtain the value in column 6, row 11 of matrix KGG and save in parameter TERM. Option P1 = ‘DTI’ Extract a real, integer, complex, or character value from a table. Format: Input Data Block: Parameters:ICOL Input -integer -default=1. Column number of matrix element. IROW Input -integer -default=1. Row number of matrix element. REAL Output -real. Real part of matrix element. IMAG Output -real. Imaginary part of matrix element, if element is complex. PARAML KGG//’DMI’/6/11/S,N,TERM/S,N,NOKGG $ PARAML TAB//’DTI’/S,N,RECNUM/S,N,WRDNUM/ S,N,REAL/S,N,INTGR/S,N,IMAG/S,N,CHAR/ S,N,RECNEW//S,N,INTNEW $ TAB Any table. RECNUM Input/output -integer. Record number of value . WRDNUM Input/output -integer. Word number of value . REAL Output -real. Real part of value . INTGR Output -integer. Integer value . IMAG Output -real. Imaginary part of value . CHAR Output -character. Character value . The first four characters in CHAR contain the table value. The second four characters are blank. RECNEW Output-integer. Record number in which table value at WORDNM-th word is nonzero for RECNUM=-1 or changes for RECNUM=-2. INTNEW Output-integer. Nonzero (RECNUM=-1) or changed (RECNUM=-2) value of WORDNM-th word in RECNEW-th record.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2368 Main Index Remark: 1.If RECNUM is greater than the number of records in table, then RECNUM is set to -1. All other parameters remain unchanged. 2.If WRDNUM is greater than the number of words in RECNUM record, then WRDNUM is set to -1. All other parameters remain unchanged. 3.If RECNUM = -1, then the WRDNUM-th word in all records will be scanned for a nonzero value. If any exist, then INTGR will be set to -1. 4.If RECNUM = -2, then all records will be scanned for changes in the value of the WRDNUM-th word. If the value changes then INTGR will be set to -1. Examples: 1.Extract the frequencies from FRL. TYPE PARM,,I,,KNT $ TYPE PARM,,LOGI,,LPFLG=TRUE $ DO WHILE ( LPFLG ) $ KNT=KNT+1 $ PARAML FRL//‘DTI’/1/S,N,KNT/S,N,FREQ $ IF ( KNT>-1 ) THEN $ MESSAGE //’ FREQ=’/FREQ $ . . . ELSE LPFLG=FALSE $ ENDIF $ ENDDO $ 2.Test for an SPCFORCE Case Control command in any subcase. According to Data Blocks (Ch. 2), SPCFORCE requests are declared in word 135 of the CASECC data block. PARAML CASECC//’DT1’/-1/135//S,N,SPCREQ $ Option P1 = ‘DTI2’ Extract double precision load factor stored in two consecutive words of the ESTNL data block and truncate to single precision. Format: Input Data Block: Parameters:PARAML ESTNL//‘DTI2’/S,N,RECNUM/S,N,WRDNUM/S,N,REAL $ ESTNL Material nonlinear element summary table. RECNUM Input/output-integer. Record number of value.

2369 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Remarks: 1.This option is so far only applicable to the load factor stored in the ESTNL data block. 2.If RECNUM is greater than the number of records in table, then RECNUM is set to -1. All other parameters remain unchanged. 3.If WRDNUM is greater than the number of words in RECNUM record, then WRDNUM is set to -1. All other parameters remain unchanged. Example: Extract load factor in words 5 and 6 of the header record. PARAML ESTNL//‘DTI2’/0/5/S,N,FACT $ LOAD FACTOR Option P1 = ‘DTI2C’ Extract character value stored in two consecutive words. Format: Input Data Block: Parameters: Remarks: 1.If RECNUM is greater than the number of records in table, then RECNUM is set to -1. All other parameters remain unchanged. 2.If WRDNUM is greater than the number of words in the RECNUM-th record, then WRDNUM is set to -1. All other parameters remain unchanged. 3.If RECNUM = -1, then the WRDNUM-th word in all records will be scanned for a nonzero value. If any exist, then INTGR will be set to -1.WRDNUM Input/output-integer. First word number of value. REAL Output-real. Real part of value. PARAML TAB//‘DTI2C’/S,N,RECNUM/S,N,WRDNUM// S,N,INTGR//S,N,CHAR2 $ TAB Any table. RECNUM Input/output-integer. Record number of value. WRDNUM Input/output-integer. First word number of value. INTGR Output-integer. Integer value and search flag when RECNUM<0. CHAR2 Output-character. Character value concatenated from the values in the WRDNUM and (WRDNUM+1)-th position.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2370 Main Index 4.If RECNUM = -2, then all records will be scanned for changes in the value in the WRDNUM-th word. If the value changes, then INTGR will be set to -1. Example: Extract the K2PP Case Control DMIG name specification words 139 and 140 of the Case Control data block. PARAML CASECC//‘DTI2C’/1/139////S,N,K2PP $ Option P1=’ EXTBULK ’ Given a Bulk Data entry name extract its record from an IFP table. Format: Input Data Block: IFPDB IFP table; e.g., GEOM1, EPT, DYNAMIC, etc. Output Data Block: IFPREC Same as IFPDB except it contains only the record associated with BLKNAM Parameter: Example: Extract MAT1 record from the MPT table. PARAML MPT/MAT1REC/‘EXTBULK’//////‘MAT1’/S,N,NOMAT1 $ Option P1=‘HEAD’ Given a Bulk Data entry name extract its header words, instance length, and number of instances. Format: Input Data Blocks: None. Output Data Blocks: None.PARAML IFPDB/IFPREC/‘EXTBULK’//////BLKNAM/S,N,NOREC $ BLKNAM Input-character. Name of Bulk Data entry. NOREC Output-integer. Record found flag. Set to -1 if record not found. PARAML //‘HEAD’/S,N,H1/S,N,H2/S,N,H3/S,N,LEN/S,N,KNT/BLKNAM $

2371 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Parameter: Example: Extract header words, etc. for the CQUAD4 Bulk Data entry. PARAML //‘HEAD’/S,N,H1/S,N,H2/S,N,H3/S,N,LEN/S,N,KNT/’CQUAD4’ $ Option P1 = ‘IMATCH’ Search for a specific integer value in a table record. Format: Input Data Block: Parameter: Example: Search for value of HINDEX in record 1 of KVAL table. HINDEX = HINDEX +1 $ PARAML KVAL//‘IMATCH’/HINDEX//S,N,NOKVAL $ Option P1 = ‘NAME’ Return the name and purge status of a data block. Format:H1 Output-integer. Header word 1. H2 Output-integer. Header word 2. H3 Output-real. Header word 3. LEN Output-integer. Length of single instance. KNT Output-real. Number of instances. BLKNAM Input-character. Name of Bulk Data entry. PARAML TAB//‘IMATCH’/RECNUM/IVALUE//S,N,FOUND $ TAB Any table. RECNUM Input-integer. Record number for search. IVALUE Input-integer. Value to search. FOUND Output-integer. Set to -1 if value is found, set to +1 otherwise. PARAML /DBNAME/‘NAME’////S,N,NODB//S,N,NAME $

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2372 Main Index Input Data Block: None. Output Data Block: Parameters: Remarks: 1.This option is useful for checking to see if the data block is purged on the CALL statement(s) in the calling subDMAP(s).
2.If DBNAME is specified on the SUBDMAP statement, then NAME is the name appearing on the corresponding CALL statement. This process is repeated until the DBNAME no longer appears on a SUBDMAP statement. Example: Check the name and purge status of the MAA matrix. PARAML /MAA/‘NAME’////S,N,NOMAA//S,N,MAANAM $ Option P1 = ‘NULL’ Test for a null or full matrix. Format: Input Data Block: Parameters:DBNAME Any data block. NODB Output-integer. Set to -1 if the data block is purged, and +1 if the data block is present. NAME Output-character. Name of the data block. Set to blank if data block is purged. PARAML MAT//‘NULL’//S,N,FULLMAT//S,N,NULLMAT $ MAT Any matrix. FULLMAT Output-integer. Flag to indicate whether matrix is full or not. 1 full 0 not full NULLMAT Output-integer. Set to -1 if matrix is null.

2373 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Example: Determine if data block PG is null. Option P1=‘PARAM’ Check for the presence of a parameter PVT table. Format: Input Data Block: Parameters: Remark: 1.The PVT table is output by the IFP and PVT modules. Example: Check for the presence of PARAM,AUTOSPC. Option P1 = ‘PRESENCE’ Test for the presence (existence) of a data block. Format: Input Data Block:PARAML PG//‘NULL’////S,N,NOPG $ PARAML PVT//‘PARAM’///// PARAM1/S,N,NOPARM1/PARAM2/S,N,NOPARM2/ PARAM3/S,N,NOPARM3/PARAM4/S,N,NOPARM4/ PARAM5/S,N,NOPARM5/PARAM6/S,N,NOPARM6/ PARAM7/S,N,NOPARM7/PARAM8/S,N,NOPARM8/ PARAM9/S,N,NOPARM9/PARAM10/S,N,NOPARM10/ PARAM11/S,N,NOPARM11/PARAM12/S,N,NOPARM12 $ PVT Parameter value table. PARAMi Input-character. Parameter name. NOPARMi Output-integer. If parameter exists then NOPARMi=-1, otherwise, +1. PARAML PVT//‘PARAM’//////‘AUTOSPC’/S,N,NOAUTOSP $ PARAML DB//‘PRESENCE’////S,N,NODB $ DB Any data block.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2374 Main Index Parameter: Remark: See DBSTATUS, 1650 module description for alternative options. Example: Test for the existence of the KGG data block.

Option P1=‘SET’ Extract elements of a SET defined in Case Control. Format: Input Data Block: Parameters: Example: Extract the members of the sample Case Control command: K2GG=MATA MATB MATC (Word 338 in CASECC contains the internal set identification number for K2GG.)NODB Output-integer. Set to -1 if the data block does not exist. PARAML KGG//‘PRESENCE’////S,N,NOKGG $ PARAML CASECC//‘SET’/S,N,RECNUM/S,N,WRDNUM/S,N,REAL/ S,N,INTGR//S,N,CHAR/S,N,SETKNTR $ CASECC T able of Case Control selections. RECNUM Input/output-integer. Record number. WRDNUM Input/output-integer. Word number of Case Control command selection which references the desired set. REAL Output-real. Real part of value in the set. INTGR Output-integer. Integer value in the set. IMAG Output-real. Imaginary part in the set. CHAR Output-character. Character value in the set. SETKNTR Input/output-integer. Pointer to desired member in set; e.g., 1 means first member in set, 2 means second member, etc. If the set is exhausted then SETKNTR is reset to -1. PARAML CASECC//‘SET’/1/338////S,N,MATNAM/S,N,SETKNTR $

2375 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Option P1=‘TABDEL’ Delete a group of words in a record, the trailing portion of a record, or the entire record in a table. Format: Input Data Block: Output Data Block: Parameters: Remark: The usage implies that the use of WORDNUM=0 and WORDNUM=-1 will both result in the deletion of the entire record number RECNUM. Example: 1.In record 18 delete word 12: PARAML DYN_SX/DYN_SX1/‘TABDEL’/18/12 $ or: FILE DYN_SX=APPEND $ PARAML /DYN_SX/‘TABDEL’/18/12 $ 2.In record 18 delete words 12 through 19: PARAML DYN_SX/DYN_SX1/‘TABDEL’/18/12//8 $PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/’TABDEL’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM//NWORDS $ TABIN Any table. May be purged in which case TABIN is specified in the output position and must be declared append; i.e., FILE TABOUT=APPEND. TABOUT Modified TABIN. The trailer of TABOUT will be the same as that of TABIN. RECNUM Input-integer >= 0. Record number. If RECNUM is greater than the number of records in TABIN, it will result in a fatal error. (RECNUM=0 refers to the header record of TABIN.) WORDNUM Input-integer. Word number.

0 A total of NWORDS entries starting from word number WORDNUM (and going forward) are deleted from record number RECNUM. If NWORDS is not specified, it is assumed to be 1. =0 Delete the entire record number RECNUM. NWORDS is ignored in this case. <0 Delete the trailing portion of record number RECNUM starting from word number ABS(WORDNUM). NWORDS is ignored in this case. NWORDS Input-integer > 0. Number of words to delete.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2376 Main Index 3.In record 7 delete from word 88 to the end of the record: PARAML DYN_SX/DYN_SX1/‘TABDEL’/7/-88 $ 4.Delete record 18: PARAML NLGM4/XXXX/‘TABDEL’/18/0 $

2377 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Option P1=‘TABINSR’, ‘TABINSI’, ‘TABINSC’, and ‘TABINS2C’ Insert a new value in a record or insert a new record after an existing record in a table. Format for P1=‘TABINSR’: Insert the real number REAL before or after word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM. Format for P1=‘TABINSI’: Insert the integer number INTEG before or after word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM. Format for P1=‘TABINSC’: Insert the first of the two 4-character strings comprising the 8-character parameter CHAR before or after word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM. Format for P1=‘TABINS2C’: Insert the two 4-character strings comprising the 8-character parameter CHAR before or after word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM. Input Data Block: Output Data Block:PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/’TABINSR’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM/REAL $ PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/’TABINSI’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM//INTEG $ PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/’TABINSC’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM////CHAR $ PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/’TABINS2C’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM////CHAR $ TABIN Any table. May be purged in which case TABIN is specified in the output position and must be declared append; i.e., FILE TABOUT=APPEND. TABOUT Modified TABIN. The trailer of TABOUT will be the same as that of TABIN.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2378 Main Index Parameters: Example: 1.In the first record after the 6th word, insert integer value 1200: PARAML CASE00/CASE01/‘TABINSI’/1/6//1200 $ or FILE CASE00=APPEND $ PARAML /CASE00/‘TABINSI’/1/6//1200 $ 2.In the first record before the 468th word, insert integer value 1: PARAML CASE00/CASE01/‘TABINSI’/1/-468//1 $ 3.In the third record after the 42nd word, insert real value 67.0: PARAML CASEC2/CASEC3/‘TABINSR’/3/42/67. $ 4.After the second record, insert a new record with real value 3.4 in the first word: PARAML OUPV1/OUPV1Z/‘TABINSR’/2/0/3.4 $ Option P1=‘TABREPR’, ‘TABREPI’, ‘TABREPC’, and ‘TABREP2C’ Replace any value in any record of a table. Format for P1=‘TABREPR’: Replace word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM by real number REAL.RECNUM Input-integer >= 0. Record number. If RECNUM is greater than the number of records in TABIN, it will result in a fatal error. (RECNUM=0 refers to the header record of TABIN.) WORDNUM Input-integer. Word number.

0 The new value is inserted AFTER word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM. <0 The new value is inserted BEFORE word number ABS(WORDNUM) in record number RECNUM. =0 A new record containing the new value is inserted AFTER record number RECNUM. REAL Input-real. New real number to be inserted in TABIN. INTEG Input-integer. New integer number to be inserted in TABIN. CHAR Input-character. New character string(s) to be inserted in TABIN. PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/‘TABREPR’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM/REAL $

2379 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Format for P1=‘TABREPI’: Replace word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM by integer number INTEG. Format for P1=‘TABREPC’: Replace word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM by the first of the two 4-character strings comprising the 8-character parameter CHAR. Format for P1=‘TABREP2C’: Replace word number WORDNUM in record number RECNUM by the two 4-character strings comprising the 8-character parameter CHAR. Input Data Block: Output Data Block: Parameters: Remark: It is the user’s responsibility to ensure that the type of word that is being replaced is the same as the type of word that is replacing it. The program does not check for this condition.PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/‘TABREPI’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM//INTEG $ PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/‘TABREPC’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM////CHAR $ PARAML TABIN/TABOUT/‘TABREP2C’/ RECNUM/WORDNUM////CHAR $ TABIN Any table. May be purged in which case TABIN is specified in the output position and must be declared append; i.e., FILE TABOUT=APPEND. TABOUT Modified TABIN. The trailer of TABOUT will be the same as that of TABIN. RECNUM Input-integer >= 0. Record number. If RECNUM is greater than the number of records in TABIN, it will result in a fatal error. (RECNUM=0 refers to the header record of TABIN.) WORDNUM Input-integer > 0. Word number. WORDNUM is the word number in record number RECNUM that is to be replaced. If this value is greater than the number of words in record number RECNUM, it will result in a fatal error. REAL Input-real. Replacement real number for TABIN. INTEG Input-integer. Replacement integer number for TABIN. CHAR Input-character. Replacement character string(s) for TABIN.

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2380 Main Index Example: 1.In the first record replace the 468th word with integer value 1: PARAML CASE00/CASE01/‘TABREPI’/1/468//1 $ or: FILE CASE00=APPEND $ PARAML /CASE00/‘TABREPI’/1/468//1 $ 2.In the second record replace the 5th word with real value 4.0: PARAML OUPV1/OUPV1Z/‘TABREPR’/2/5/4. $ 3.In the first record replace the 7th word with character string ‘STAT’: PARAML CASEX1/CASEX2/‘TABREPC’/1/7////‘STAT’ $ 4.In the fourth record replace the 96th and 97th words with character strings ‘ST/P’ and ‘EM’, respectively: PARAML CASEXX/CASEMOD/‘TABREP2C’/4/96////‘ST/PEM’ $ Option P1 = ‘TRAILER’ Extract a value from the trailer of a data block or set information from USET. Format for all data blocks except USET: Format for USET table: Input Data Block: Parameter:PARAML DB//‘TRAILER’/WRDNUM/S,N,TVALUE/S,N,REAL/S,N,NODB $ PARAML USET//‘TRAILER’////S,N,NOSET//SETNAME $ DB Any data block. USET Degree-of-freedom set membership table. WRDNUM Input-integer. Word number of trailer. TVALUE Output-integer. T railer value. See T able in Remark 1. REAL Output-real. T railer value as a real number. Used only if WRDNUM=6. See Remark 2. NODB Output-integer. Set to -1 if the data block does not exist. NOSET Output-integer. USET flag for existence for the set specified by SETNAME. NOSET will be set to -1 if the set does not exist. SETNAME Input-character. Degree-of-freedom set name.

2381 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Remarks: 1.Meaning of TVALUE:

2.If WRDNUM=6, the density of a matrix is returned as an integer value times 10000 in TVALUE and also as a real value in REAL. If the density is greater than 99.999%, but not actually full, then TVALUE will be 10000, which is misleading if one is checking for the “fullness” of a matrix. It is recommended that either the REAL parameter be checked or the FULLMAT parameter be checked under P1=’NULL’. Examples: 1.Extract the second word of the trailer from the SILS table and save in LUSETS: PARAML SILS/‘TRAILER’/2/S,N,LUSETS//S,N,NOSILS $ 2.Check for the presence of single-point constraints (s-set): PARAML USET//’TRAILER’////S,N,SINGLE//’S’ $ Option P1 = ‘USET’ Search for a specific integer value in a table record.WRDNUM Meaning of TVALUE 1 Number of columns in matrix 2 Number of rows in matrix 3 Form of the matrix 4 Type of matrix 5 Largest number of nonzero words among all columns 6 Density of the matrix multiplied by 10000 7 Size in blocks 8 Maximum string length over all strings 9 Number of strings 10 Average bandwidth 11 Maximum bandwidth 12 Number of null columns

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2382 Main Index Format: Input Data Block: Parameter: Remark: See TRAILER option for allowable set names. Example: Check for the existence of multipoint constraints (MPCs), rigid elements, and single -point constraints (SPCs). PARAML USET//’USET’//////’M’/S,N,NOMSET/’S’/S,N,NOSSET $ Option P1=’VERSID’, ‘VERSID1’, ‘VERSID2’, ‘VERSID3’, ‘VERSID4’, and ‘VERSDATE’ Extract the program version information as shown in f06 title page banner.
Formats: Extract the program version id number; e.g., ‘2004.0.0’: Extract the program version label 1; e.g., ‘MSC Nastran – Tier 2’: Extract the program version label 2; e.g., ‘Customer Funded Project’:PARAML USET//‘USET’////// SET1/S,N,NOSET1/SET2/S,N,NOSET2/ SET3/S,N,NOSET3/SET4/S,N,NOSET4/ SET5/S,N,NOSET5/SET6/S,N,NOSET6/ SET7/S,N,NOSET7/SET8/S,N,NOSET8/ SET9/S,N,NOSET9/SET10/S,N,NOSET10/ SET11/S,N,NOSET11/SET12/S,N,NOSET12 $ USET Degree-of-freedom set membership table. SETi Input-character. Degree-of-freedom Set name. NOSETi Output-integer. Degree-of-freedom Set existence flag. NOSETi = -1 if set does not exist. NOSETi = number of degrees of freedom in the set if the set exists. PARAML //’VERSID’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ PARAML //’VERSID1’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $

item.title: User's Manual P121
item.description:
2383 PARAML Sets parameters from a data block Main Index Extract the program version label 3; e.g., ‘Evalulation System’: Extract the program version label 4: Extract the program build date: Input Data Blocks: None. Output Data Blocks: None. Parameter: Remarks: 1.The CHARi values may be best displayed with: Option P1=‘XYCDB’ Check for the presence of a response types specified on xy plotting commands: XYPAPLOT , XYPEAK, XYPLOT, XYPRINT and XYPUNCH.PARAML //’VERSID2’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ PARAML //’VERSID3’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ PARAML //’VERSID4’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ PARAML //’VERSDATE’//////S,N,CHAR1//S,N,CHAR2// S,N,CHAR3//S,N,CHAR4 $ CHARi Output-character. Up to 32 characters are extracted into CHARi the values which when concatenated form the complete label. MESSAGE //CHAR1/CHAR2/CHAR3/CHAR4 $

MSC Nastran DMAP Programmer’s Guide Sets parameters from a data block2384 Main Index Format: Input Data Block: Parameters: See X-Y PLOT Commands (p.686) in the for a description of the types. Example: Check for the presence of the MPCF response type. PARAML XYCDBS//‘XYCDB’//////‘MPCF’/S,N,NOMPCF $PARAML XYCDB//‘XYCDB’///// RESP1/S,N,NORESP1/RESP2/S,N,NORESP2/ RESP3/S,N,NORESP3/RESP4/S,N,NORESP4/ RESP5/S,N,NORESP5/RESP6/S,N,NORESP6/ RESP7/S,N,NORESP7/RESP8/S,N,NORESP8/ RESP9/S,N,NORESP9/RESP10/S,N,NORESP10/ RESP11/S,N,NORESP11/RESP12/S,N,NORESP12 $ XYCDB T able of x-y plotting commands. Response type. RESPi Input-character. The valid names are: DISP VELO ACCE SPCF OLOA VG STRE FORC SDIS SVEL SACC NFOR PRES BOUT STRA MPCF FPRE FMPF SMPF PMPF LMPF GMPF NORESPi Output-integer. If the response type was is specified on an xy plotting command then NORESPi=1, otherwise, -1.

2385 PARSEN Partition the design variables for multiple processors Main Index Partition the design variables for multiple processors. Format: Input Data Blocks: Output Data Blocks:PARSEN Partition the design variables for multiple processors PARSEN TABDEQ ,DTOS2* ,DTOS4 ,DESGID ,DELBSH , TOPVOL0 ,TOTVOL0 ,DESTAB , EDOM* ,DSLIST , DXDXI SEDVLST0,SEDVLST1/ TABDEQP ,DTOS2P ,DTOS4P ,DESGIDP ,DELBSHP , VDEQ ,TOPVOLP ,TOTVOLP ,DSLISTP ,SEDVLST2/ S,N,PROTYP/PROCID/NPROC /SEID $ TABDEQ Table of unique design variable identification numbers. DTOS2* Family of tables which are the same as DTOS2K* except that the PREF in each entry is the product of a DPLDXI element and the corresponding design variable value. DTOS4 Same as DTOS4K except that the last three words in each entry contains the product of those in DTOS4K and the shape step size. DESGID Table of designed grid coordinate attributes. DELBSH Matrix of finite difference shape step sizes. TOPVOL0 Table containing topological designable element volume based on property ID. TOTVOL0 Table containing topological designable element volume based on TOPVAR entry ID. DESTAB Table of design variable attributes. EDOM* Family of EDOM tables for all superelements.
